awd_titl_txt: Knots and contact topology through holomorphic curves
awd_abstract_narration:
The subjects of mathematics and physics have always been closely intertwined, with each one motivating and informing progress in the other. This project focuses on one current area of interplay, between topology (the study of shapes) on the mathematical side and string theory on the physics side. The jumping-off point for the project is an intriguing and unexpected connection, recently discovered by the Principal Investigator and collaborators on both sides, between two separate algebraic structures associated to knots in space: one in topology developed by the Principal Investigator, and one in string theory that has been the focus of much research in the past few years. In the course of this project, the Principal Investigator will establish this connection, which is currently only supported circumstantially; it is hoped that this work will create and strengthen new lines of communication between mathematics and physics, introducing techniques from each discipline into the other. The Principal Investigator will also use this project to train future mathematicians at all levels, from contributing to the annual USA Mathematical Olympiad for high school students, to supervising the research of undergraduates, graduate students, and postdoctoral fellows, to organizing conferences and seminars for established researchers.

In the past decade, the Principal Investigator has introduced and studied a package of knot invariants called knot contact homology, which arises by counting holomorphic curves in certain symplectic manifolds, using a method in symplectic geometry pioneered by Gromov and Floer and more recently culminating in the Symplectic Field Theory of Eliashberg, Givental, and Hofer. Previous work has shown that knot contact homology is a robust invariant that is effective at distinguishing knots and contains classical topological information about the knot. In 2012, it was discovered by Aganagic, Ekholm, Vafa, and the Principal Investigator that knot contact homology has an unexpected and potentially powerful relation to string theory and mirror symmetry: the augmentation polynomial, a knot invariant derived from knot contact homology, is conjectured to be equal to Aganagic and Vafa's Q-deformed A-polynomial, which arises in the context of topological strings. The Principal Investigator will approach this conjecture using Lagrangian fillings and Gromov-Witten potentials. This could have significant ramifications in different directions: in knot theory, it would establish a variant of the AJ conjecture; in mirror symmetry, it would produce a new approach via Symplectic Field Theory to constructing mirror Calabi-Yau 3-folds; and in topological string theory, it would provide a mathematical foundation for recent results. In related work, the Principal Investigator will develop and strengthen the algebraic framework underneath certain aspects of Symplectic Field Theory, including knot contact homology and symplectic homology. New algebraic tools in this context, such as representation theory for differential graded algebras, would enable one to more effectively attack problems in symplectic geometry, in particular by analyzing Weinstein structures on symplectic manifolds and Legendrian and transverse knots in contact manifolds.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The main research goal of this project was to use techniques from sympectic geometry to study an area of topology concerning the theory of knots. Symplectic geometry is an area of mathematics that dates back to the 19th century and the framework of Newtonian mechanics in physics. Prior to this project, the Principal Investigator and collaborators developed a theory that associates, to any knot, a package of algebraic structures collectively known as knot contact homology. It was known that knot contact homology constitutes quite a strong invariant of knots, in particular containing several classical knot invariants such as the Alexander polynomial within its structure. It was however an open question exactly how strong this invariant is.

A main result of this project is a rigorous proof that knot contact homology is a complete knot invariant: that is, if two knots have identical knot contact homology, then they must be the same knot. Loosely speaking, this says that knot contact homology is as strong as it could possibly be. This result comes from joint work between Ekholm, Shende, and the PI. It might be noted that although a large variety of knot invariants have been developed by mathematicians in the past few decades, very few of them have been shown to be complete knot invariants, and indeed most of them have been shown not to be.

The project also developed and strengthened links between the subject of symplectic geometry and a number of other subjects in mathematics and physics. In joint work with Rutherford, Shende, Sivek, and Zaslow, the PI introduced an algebraic object called the augmentation category, associated to particular types of knots called Legendrian knots, and proved that the augmentation category is the same as a completely different type of object, a sheaf category defined by Shende, Treumann, and Zaslow. This established a new connection between symplectic geometry and the subject of algebraic geometry. In joint work with Ekholm, the PI laid out a program that relates knot contact homology in a specific way to another collection of algebraic knot invariants studied by other mathematicians, the colored HOMFLY-PT polynomials. This completely unexpected relation ties together symplectic geometry and the subject of quantum topology. In fact, the relation runs through a subject in physics called topological string theory, and work of the PI through this project has been of use to physicists in their own research in string theory.

Besides the PI, this project supported research by two postdoctoral fellows and four graduate students providing funding for research assistantships and travel to conferences to collaborate with other mathematicians. The project also helped to establish a new collaborative research program for undergraduates at Duke University, Duke Opportunities in Mathematics. Over the first two years of this program?s existence, this project provided research funds for four undergraduates to undertake summer supervised research in mathematics in collaboration with other students. The project facilitated research at the high school level as well, with the PI leading a yearlong research project in mathematics for three students from the North Carolina School of Science and Mathematics. In addition, the project helped to support the PI?s work in promoting recreational mathematics, including the problems section of the journal The American Mathematical Monthly and undergraduate math competitions such as the Putnam competition.

 


Last Modified: 11/23/2018
Modified by: Lenhard L Ng
